text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single-column page with two sequential register illustrations; the top scene is set beneath a decorative arch with the modern title ‘Moses and Aaron’ typeset to its right, the lower scene occupying the full width of the page without adjacent text. Wide blank margins separate and frame each scene, creating a clear visual hierarchy.

color_scheme.color_usage: Monochrome line drawing in pen and ink for scholarly reproduction; no pigments or metallics present.

features: Gestural flow from top scene to bottom

decorative_elements: Stylized wavy lines representing parted waters

drawing_technique.line_style: Clear, precise ink outlines of uniform weight, with minimal variation.
drawing_technique.shading_method: Virtually no hatching or tonal gradation; volume implied by contour only.
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Flat, schematic perspective; spatial depth indicated only by overlapping figures.

reading_order: Upper register: Moses and Aaron before Pharaoh
Lower register: Moses leading Israelites through parted sea

scene_relationships.subject: Moses and Aaron before Pharaoh
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Precedes the miracle of the Red Sea, establishing royal permission for the Exodus
visual_connections: Moses/Aaron staff motif echoed in second scene
Raised right-hand gesture mirrored by Moses in lower scene
Fine drapery folds rendered identically in both registers
Overlapping figures provide similar spatial ordering
Baseline indicating ground in both scenes

scene_relationships.subject: Moses leading Israelites through the parted Red Sea
visual_connections: Continuation of staff held by central figure
Raised hand gesture indicating divine authority
Consistent line quality and drapery treatment
Grouping of figures in close procession
Use of simple wavy line pattern to denote water

visual_continuity: Repetition of the staff as central attribute
Raised-hand gesture in both central figures

content_theme.scene_description: In the upper register, Pharaoh is enthroned beneath a semicircular arch supported by two columns with vegetal capitals. He wears a crown of three fleurons, his robe falling in finely incised folds. His right hand is extended in dispensation. To his left stands Aaron, identifiable by the long staff he holds upright; his tunic sleeves are rendered in a diamond-pattern hatch. The throne sits on a two-step dais decorated with geometric motifs. In the lower register, Moses leads a group of Israelites—men, women and children—across the parted Red Sea. He advances barefoot, staff in hand, gesturing toward stylized wavy lines that represent the divided waters. Behind him, a double-humped camel and a procession of figures overlap to suggest depth. Both scenes rely on clear contour lines and minimal shading to convey form and narrative.

technical_features.material: Calf vellum with a smooth, well-prepared surface; pen-and-ink drawing directly on skin.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Ink lines remain crisp and intact; no visible fading or pigment loss; page has minimal surface soiling.
notable_physical_characteristics: Consistent plummet ruling underdrawing visible in margins
Fine, even ink application with no brush strokes
Absence of color or gold leaf
Sharp contours with no evidence of later retouching

functional_analysis.primary_function: Didactic biblical illustration (exemplum for teaching or devotional reading)
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Clerical or monastic readership engaged in scriptural study

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This two-register illustration likely dates to a twelfth- or early thirteenth-century monastic workshop, reflecting the didactic emphasis on Old Testament types. The precise pen­work and absence of polychromy suggest a preparatory drawing or a scholarly exemplar rather than a deluxe choir book. The upper scene’s architectural framing and throne iconography recall Carolingian and Ottonian precedents, while the lower register’s schematic waves relate to Insular manuscript models. The work exhibits a synthesis of continental Northern Romanesque conventions—especially in the stylized vegetal capitals—and emerging Gothic linearity visible in the naturalistic drapery folds. Iconographically, the parallel raised-hand gestures in both scenes underscore Moses and Aaron’s divinely delegated authority: first mediating before Pharaoh, then commanding the waters. The camel and grouped Israelites convey the social dimension of the Exodus as a communal salvation. Comparisons with the illustrated Bibles of La Madeleine de Vézelay suggest a similar workshop milieu, though the monochrome format indicates a different functional context, perhaps as a model for multiple reproductions. Overall, this drawing exemplifies transitional manuscript culture at the cusp of the thirteenth century, balancing tradition and innovation in service of theological pedagogy.
